Content: status of the debtor's checking account with the bank (categorical)
credit duration in months (quantitative)
history of compliance with previous or concurrent credit contracts (categorical)
purpose for which the credit is needed (categorical)
credit amount in DM (quantitative; result of monotonic transformation; actual data and type of transformation unknown)
debtor's savings (categorical)
duration of debtor's employment with current employer (ordinal; discretized quantitative)
credit installments as a percentage of debtor's disposable income (ordinal; discretized quantitative)

combined information on sex and marital status; categorical; sex cannot be recovered from the variable, because male singles and female non - singles are coded with the same code(2); female widows cannot be easily classified,because the code table does not list them in any of the female categories
Is there another debtor or a guarantor for the credit? (categorical)
length of time (in years) the debtor lives in the present residence (ordinal; discretized quantitative)

the debtor's most valuable property, i.e. the highest possible code is used. Code 2 is used, if codes 3 or 4 are not applicable and there is a car or any other relevant property that does not fall under variable sparkont.(ordinal)
age in years (quantitative)
installment plans from providers other than the credit-giving bank (categorical)
type of housing the debtor lives in (categorical)
number of credits including the current one the debtor has (or had) at this bank (ordinal, discretized quantitative); contrary to Fahrmeir(1984) statement, the original data values are not available.
quality of debtor's job (ordinal)
number of persons who financially depend on the debtor (i.e., are entitled to maintenance) (binary,discretized quantitative)
Is there a telephone landline registered on the debtor's name? (binary; remember that the data are from the 1970 s)
Is the debtor a foreign worker? (binary)
Has the credit contract been complied with (good) or not (bad) ? (binary)
